conclusion: To determine the trend of the acceleration of object B during the time interval from 0 to \( t_2 \), we need to analyze the velocity-time (v-t) graph for object B.
The graph for object B is the curve labeled 'B' in the image.
Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time.
On a v-t graph, the slope of the tangent to the curve at any point represents the acceleration at that instant.
At \( t = 0 \), the slope of the curve for object B is positive.

premise: At \( t = 0 \), the slope of the curve for object B is positive.
conclusion: The object is accelerating at \( t = 0 \).
As time progresses from 0 to \( t_1 \), the slope of the curve decreases.

premise: As time progresses from 0 to \( t_1 \), the slope of the curve decreases.
conclusion: The acceleration is decreasing from 0 to \( t_1 \).
At \( t = t_1 \), the slope of the curve is zero.

premise: At \( t = t_1 \), the slope of the curve is zero.
conclusion: The acceleration is zero at \( t_1 \).
From \( t_1 \) to \( t_2 \), the slope of the curve becomes negative.

premise: From \( t_1 \) to \( t_2 \), the slope of the curve becomes negative.
conclusion: The object is decelerating (negative acceleration) from \( t_1 \) to \( t_2 \).

premise: From 0 to \( t_1 \), the acceleration decreases from a positive value to zero. From \( t_1 \) to \( t_2 \), the acceleration becomes negative and increases in magnitude (becomes more negative).
conclusion: The acceleration of object B decreases from a positive value to zero and then becomes more negative as time progresses from 0 to \( t_2 \).
